name: NPR
text: Experts say the rise of mutual aid groups — in which ordinary people volunteer to help one another in neighborhoods where the government won't or can't — shows that people can be at their best during moments of disaster.  https://t.co/pygDKT5hvI

name: NPR
text:
He'd been separated from his parents. He was living in a refugee camp in Sudan. And then a snake bit him.

A Lost Boy remembers the darkest moment of his life – and what gave him hope when all hope seemed to be lost. https://t.co/5tLS6LDCVc

name: NPR
text: Disability was once seen as a personal health problem. President George H.W. Bush signed the Americans With Disabilities Act into law in 1990, expanding disability rights beyond federally funded spaces. https://t.co/QNYxN0Eqvv

name: NPR
text:
With less than 100 days until Election Day, Joe Biden has a clear advantage over President Trump in the polls — but it's expected to tighten.

Here are nine factors that could change the dynamics of the race before November.
 https://t.co/DSQUQO3JCI

name: NPR
text:
A COVID-19 vaccine candidate developed by the company Moderna and the NIH begins its final phase of testing today.

It could take as many as 30,000 volunteers — and the entire process will likely take months.
https://t.co/vE1DWQdcJz

name: NPR
text:
RT @planetmoney: In the 1980s, Freeway Ricky Ross was one of the most notorious drug dealers in LA. The government was doing everything it could to make his life miserable, but by keeping drugs illegal it was also making him rich. His story is Class 3 of #PMSummerSchool.
https://t.co/iIHPObStwP https://t.co/3GfFdLILWh

text:

https://t.co/Wss8QUdzav

text:

name: NPR
text:

More from @anya1anya & the @NPRLifeKit podcast here: 

https://t.co/TDHMkARpGV

name: NPR
text:
Conner was 4 when he was diagnosed with Duchenne muscular dystrophy. After an experimental gene therapy, the now-9-year-old has regained enough muscle strength to run.

If the therapy is successful in others, it could change the lives of thousands of kids.
https://t.co/jlbFPULJBC

name: NPR
text:
Major League Baseball has postponed two Monday games over fears of a coronavirus flare-up.

The announcement comes amid reports that at least 8 players and 2 coaches from the Miami Marlins have tested positive.
https://t.co/QTfn1vS8Ad

text: Watch Live: Lawmakers honor Rep. John Lewis before he lies in state at the U.S. Capitol. https://t.co/ffV12Rz7S4

name: NPR
text:
Vietnam has reported 11 new coronavirus cases — after having no locally transmitted infections since April.

Now, the country is evacuating 80,000 people from Da Nang, a popular domestic tourism spot.
https://t.co/Bye7Kz8V2D

name: NPR
text:
Joe Biden has the clear advantage in the polls for now.

But his advantage in national polls has come largely from a drop in President Trump's support — rather than a big increase in the percentage of people saying they would vote for Biden. https://t.co/ur7rk7EA5t

text: Democrats are meeting remotely to approve a lengthy policy platform that seeks to bridge the gap between Bernie Sanders' progressive politics and Joe Biden's more moderate approach to governing. https://t.co/ZnNNYA4oaD

name: NPR
text:
Two new studies suggest flu and pneumonia vaccines may provide some protection against Alzheimer's.

One study found that people who got at least one flu shot had a 17% reduction in risk—and those with regular vaccinations had their risk drop another 13%.
https://t.co/k7sBqBc1oA

name: NPR
text:
Google is letting its employees work from home through June 2021. 

The company had previously expected most employees to return to the office by the end of this year. https://t.co/ulw1LsaNoP

name: NPR
text:
